page.title: 02WILDLIFE
page.content: The area surrounding Barton Broad is mainly wetland. Alder carr and dense reed beds provide homes for a variety of wildlife. By the side of the footpaths ragged robin, yellow flag and orchids mingle with hogweed. Milkweed also grows attracting the rare and colourful Swallowtail butterfly. Along the banks of the dykes there can be found stacks of freshly cut reeds and sedge for thatching. In and around the dykes are small frogs, water spiders and damsel fly larvae. In the water are roach, bream and minnows. The broad is also a haven for birdlife. Terns perch on the navigation posts. On the water itself are grebes, geese, moorhens, coots, swans and ducks. In the shallower water herons stalk. Occasionally pairs of marsh harriers can be seen flying over the reeds.
